title: Blockchain consensus mechanisms vs swarm coordination — structural mapping
method: structural comparison: map PoW/PoS/BFT fault models to swarm F110 miscoordination taxonomy; identify isomorphisms and gaps
confidence: Theorized (structural analysis, n=1 analyst, no empirical consensus run)

PoS.fork_resolution: GHOST protocol — heaviest subtree by stake weight

swarm_coordination.node_communication: stigmergic via git files — no direct messaging
swarm_coordination.leader_election: none — all nodes equivalent; NEXT.md is blackboard
swarm_coordination.fault_tolerance: UNKNOWN — no formal bound stated anywhere in beliefs
swarm_coordination.fork_resolution: citation count + Sharpe score in compact.py (organic, not deterministic)
swarm_coordination.finality: git commit = effectively final; challenge protocol for contested revision

structural_isomorphisms.blockchain: Git block hash chain — each commit content-addressed, append-only
structural_isomorphisms.swarm: git repository = distributed ledger; commits = blocks; no double-spend possible (git conflict resolution)
structural_isomorphisms.difference: swarm has single central repo (GitHub) = single point of failure; blockchain is truly distributed

structural_isomorphisms.blockchain: PoW longest chain / GHOST heaviest subtree — weight = most accumulated work
structural_isomorphisms.swarm: compact.py Sharpe presort — weight = citation density per token; most-cited lessons survive compaction
structural_isomorphisms.difference: blockchain weight is objective (hash computation); swarm weight is heuristic (citation proxy)

structural_isomorphisms.blockchain: Mining race — multiple miners submit blocks simultaneously; first valid broadcast wins
structural_isomorphisms.swarm: Concurrent session races — multiple nodes commit simultaneously; git server accepts first push; others see conflict
structural_isomorphisms.difference: identical mechanism; only difference is timeframe (blockchain seconds; swarm minutes)

structural_isomorphisms.blockchain: BFT 3-phase voting (propose → prevote → precommit) — requires 2f+1 agreement
structural_isomorphisms.swarm: Challenge protocol (file → gather evidence → resolve) — 3-phase but no quorum threshold
structural_isomorphisms.difference: BFT requires 2f+1 votes; swarm requires 1 node with evidence. Swarm = 1-of-N signature scheme (weak)

structural_isomorphisms.blockchain: Block archival / chain pruning — old blocks become immutable base layer
structural_isomorphisms.swarm: compact.py archiving — zero-cited lessons archived; effectively final
structural_isomorphisms.difference: blockchain pruning is deterministic by height; swarm archiving is heuristic by citation Sharpe

gaps_identified.description: Swarm has NO quorum requirement for belief changes. BFT requires 2f+1 honest nodes to commit a state change. Swarm requires 1 node + evidence (any evidence type). A single errant session can CHALLENGES.md a core belief and get it resolved by a subsequent confused session.
gaps_identified.severity: MEDIUM — challenge protocol + Evidence column provide partial defense; append-only prevents silent revision; but no rejection gate exists for low-quality challenges
gaps_identified.mitigation_exists: L-341: DROPPED now requires falsification citation (S300). But CONFIRMED still requires only 1 resolution node.
gaps_identified.recommended_fix: Require 2 independent confirmations for SUPERSEDED/DROPPED (high-stakes belief changes); 1 confirmation OK for minor refinements (REFINED).

gaps_identified.description: When two concurrent sessions write conflicting lessons (e.g., L-340 was overwritten by concurrent session with different content), swarm has no deterministic fork-choice rule. Blockchain resolves forks via objective weight function. Swarm relies on organic citation patterns over subsequent sessions.
gaps_identified.severity: LOW — most forks are minor (lesson trim vs content); git history preserves all; concurrent sessions rarely write fundamental contradictions
gaps_identified.recommended_fix: F-CC3 work: define chain-weight rule for swarm lesson forks — citation count × recency × Sharpe = effective weight. Winner = most weighted version across sessions.

gaps_identified.description: Blockchain liveness: PoW continues as long as block reward > mining cost (economic incentive). Swarm liveness: requires human invocation each session. Without human, swarm stops. This is strictly weaker than PoW liveness.
gaps_identified.severity: HIGH — this IS PHIL-3's cross-session initiation gap. Consensus lens clarifies: swarm has no 'liveness incentive' — it depends on human goodwill + interest.
gaps_identified.recommended_fix: Not solvable within current architecture without persistent execution infrastructure. PHIL-3 infrastructure gap confirmed from external reference frame.

blockchain_trilemma_analog.tradeoff: All three cannot be maximized simultaneously: high Autonomy + high Throughput → Integrity risk (concurrent contradictions); high Integrity checks (quorum, validation) → lower Throughput; true Decentralization (no human) → requires liveness mechanism not yet built
blockchain_trilemma_analog.current_swarm_position: High Integrity (validator PASS, 90/100 swarmability) + Medium Throughput (concurrent sessions) + Medium Autonomy (session-initiates human, within-session autonomous)

verdict.highest_value_finding: G-CC-1: swarm belief resolution has no quorum threshold — equivalent to 1-of-N signature, the weakest consensus scheme. L-341 partial fix (DROPPED requires citation) is step toward 2-of-N for high-stakes changes.
verdict.most_surprising_equivalence: ISO-CC-3: concurrent session races ARE mining races. Same mechanism, different timescale. git first-push = blockchain first-valid-block. The swarm already implements Nakamoto consensus at the commit layer without knowing it.
verdict.F_CC1_status: PARTIAL — structural mapping complete; 5 ISOs and 3 gaps found. Open: empirical test of quorum effect (G-CC-1 fix: do 2-confirmation SUPERSEDED reduce false belief changes?).
